I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide Pacific developing member 
countries (DMCs) with capacity-building, policy advice, and project preparation support for a 
series of ensuing projects: the Water and Sanitation Project (Cook Islands); the South Tarawa 
Water  Supply  Project,  additional  financing  (Kiribati);  the  Urban  Planning  Project  (Solomon 
Islands); and the Kosrae Water Supply and Sanitation Project (Federated States of Micronesia). 
The TA is included in the Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan, 2020–2022 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB).1 
 
2.  The TA will support the following strategic priorities of ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2016–
2020:2 enabling value creation by promoting livable and economically vibrant urban areas; 
supporting projects that will help governments follow long-term urban planning to ensure that 
urban services can be sustained; and encouraging private sector and civil society organization 
involvement in the provision of urban infrastructure and services. The TA will also support the 
Pacific Approach in providing (i) stronger, faster, and more sustainable project delivery through 
the expanded use of differentiated regional approaches and mechanisms; and (ii) improved 
generation and sharing of knowledge. 
 
3.  Pacific island countries are rapidly urbanizing. Internal migration is increasingly attracted 
to towns, as urban areas become centers of commerce, seats of government, and places of 
opportunity and hope (footnote 2). In seven of the 14 Pacific DMCs (the Cook Islands, Fiji, the 
Marshall Islands, Nauru, Niue, Palau, and Tuvalu), more than half the population lives in urban 
areas. Urbanization rates are increasing in all Pacific DMCs except the Cook Islands and Samoa.3 
At current urbanization rates, the urban population of Papua New Guinea is expected to double 
in 25 years, while the urban population of the Solomon Islands is expected to double in 17 years 
and that of Vanuatu is expected to double in 16 years. However, urban growth has been largely 
unplanned, resulting in inadequate basic urban infrastructure services such as water supply, 
sanitation, flood control, solid waste management, and urban transport; and a shortage of 
affordable serviced land and housing.4 Larger DMCs that are still predominantly rural, such as the 
Solomon Islands, have the highest urbanization growth rates, driving a growing interest in urban 
infrastructure  investment.  In  small,  low-lying  atoll  countries  such  as  the  Marshall  Islands, 
unplanned urbanization is increasing the exposure of people and critical urban assets to disasters 
and climate change risks. Risk-informed development could reduce this exposure. 
 
4.  Urbanization provides significant opportunities for social and economic development—
e.g., through greater economies of scale in the provision of basic social services, or through 
increased innovation and productivity resulting from the agglomeration of people. However, 
unplanned  urban  growth  in  the  Pacific  island  countries  is  contributing  to  environmental 
degradation as the number of under-serviced informal settlements rises and vulnerability to 
climate change and natural hazards such as flooding increases. Major investments are needed 
to improve urban planning and infrastructure and help the Pacific island countries’ towns and 
cities become livable, economically vibrant, and climate resilient. 
 
1  ADB. 2019. Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan, 2020–2022. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2016. Pacific Approach, 2016–2020. Manila. 
3  ADB. 2020. Pacific Urban Update 2019. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2016. The Emergence of Pacific Urban Villages. Urbanization Trends in the Pacific Islands. Manila.

2 
5.  Although the need for investment is great, most Pacific DMCs have limited capacity to 
prepare, manage, and coordinate major investments. They lack revenue streams to finance, 
sustain, and service such investments, while urban service delivery lacks accountability. To 
overcome these weaknesses, significant capacity building will be required. 
 
6.  Previous ADB urban projects in Pacific DMCs have highlighted the need to increase the 
capacity of institutions and staff to sustainably operate water supply and sanitation facilities and 
operations. Low capacity exists within institutions and among decision makers where a basic 
understanding of water supply and sanitation operations is often lacking. However, to ensure the 
sustainability of water supply and sanitation systems, experience has shown that capacity building 
must be accompanied by physical investments.5 
 
7.  Recent ADB TA projects in the Pacific have supported the preparation of urban sector 
analyses, reviewed urban policies, and conducted project preparatory-related assessments.6 A 
demand-driven approach and close consultations with host governments have contributed to 
successful project outcomes. However, the largely single-country focus of these projects limited 
their scope and slowed ADB’s response time to new requests for technical assistance and 
capacity  development.  Pacific  DMCs  continue  to  request  ADB  support  in  preparing  urban 
development projects, building capacity, identifying technical needs, and building knowledge. This 
TA facility is designed to respond to these requests. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Feasibility studies on ensuing urban development projects prepared. The 
TA will provide support to Pacific DMCs to prioritize, plan, and prepare investments projects for 
potential ADB financing. This will include all kinds of necessary due diligence; assessment of 
technical suitability; economic, financial and social viability; capacity and institutional issues; 
procurement due diligence; address environmental and social safeguards; address social gender 
needs  and  ensure  gender  mainstreaming;  and  identify  measures  to  strengthen  project 
implementation capacity for urban investment projects. This will enhance the efficiency of project 
preparation,  address  cross-cutting  issues,  and  will  reduce  the  transaction  costs  through 
minimizing  the  need  for  stand-alone  transaction  TAs.  Detailed  activities  will  include,  when 
required: (i) feasibility studies required for the ensuing investment; (ii) economic analysis;7  
(iii) financial management assessment, financial evaluation and financial analysis; (iv) gender 
analysis,  collection  of  baseline  data  and  gender  action  plans;  (v)  risk  assessment  and 
management plans; (vi) social safeguards documents on environment, involuntary resettlement 
and indigenous peoples; and (vii) sector assessments. 
 
9.  Initially, output 1 will mainly support feasibility studies on two ensuing urban development 
projects: the Water and Sanitation Project (Cook Islands) and the Kosrae Water Supply and 
Sanitation Project (Federated States of Micronesia). Limited support is anticipated for the South 
Tarawa Water Supply Project additional financing (Kiribati) and the Urban Planning Project 
(Solomon Islands). Once additional TA funding is available, additional feasibility support will be

TA amount and minor change in scope will be requested accordingly. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Demand-driven  urban  technical  advice,  assessment,  and  capacity 
development assistance provided. The TA will provide on-demand specialist support, technical 
advice, assessment, diagnostics, and other analytical work and capacity-building support to 
Pacific DMCs to enhance the sustainability of urban investments. Activities under this output will 
be undertaken with the engagement of government staff and national institutions, through on-the-
job and other forms of training, to help build country capacity and create a cadre of national staff 
who are familiar with the critical elements of preparing urban investments. Support will focus on 
demand-driven diagnostic analysis and financial planning (e.g., water or waste tariff reviews). 
Other areas of support will include independent peer reviews, collection and maintenance of 
accurate and sex-disaggregated data required for policy formulation, value-for-money analysis in 
urban  investment  planning,  disaster  risk  assessment,  and  capacity  building  in  gender 
mainstreaming. The TA will also support policy dialogue, negotiations, and informed decisions in 
designing  regulatory  frameworks  and  devising  investment  options.  ADB  will  evaluate  all 
government requests under this output. Requests should be linked to ongoing or immediately 
ensuing urban investments and programs within the core TA priority areas (but not necessarily 
linked to ADB potential investments) and should be outside the scope of ongoing assistance by 
other development partners. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Knowledge  sharing  among  Pacific  developing  member  countries 
enhanced. The TA will support the organization of various regional training, workshops, and 
conferences to enhance knowledge sharing among ADB Pacific DMCs and apex regional urban 
bodies. The TA will also support, when required, the production of knowledge products, taking 
into consideration lessons from the formulation of laws and infrastructure investment experiences, 
human resource capacity development, and gender mainstreaming in urban projects in the Pacific. 
In particular, the TA will support the Pacific Water and Wastewater Association in organizing the 
annual Pacific Water Conference, and will work in close collaboration with ADB’s urban and water 
sector groups to collect and disseminate lessons and knowledge products to policy makers, line 
ministries, urban planners in Pacific DMCs, and within ADB. Where applicable, the Pacific Water 
and  Wastewater  Association8 and  the  Pacific  Regional  Infrastructure  Facility9 Water  and 
Sanitation Sector Working Group may be mobilized to assist in this process. This output will help 
increase awareness of other countries’ activities and strengthen links and networking for future 
collaboration. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1.6 million, of which $1.5 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6 and TASF-Others). The 
government will provide in-kind contribution, which is estimated to be about $100,000. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The participating governments will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions. 
The governments have been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. 
 
 
8  www.pwwa.ws. 
9  www.theprif.org.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The TA activities for an ensuing project will start only after ADB approves the project 
concept paper on the ensuing project. Ensuing projects expected to be supported by the TA in 
terms of feasibility studies and project preparation are listed in Appendix 2 and are expected to 
be approved during the 2020–2021 period. 
 
15.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  and  implementing  agency 
responsible  for  consultant  recruitment  in  close  consultation  with  participating  governments. 
Concurrence will be sought from participating governments for short-listing of consultants. ADB’s 
main government counterpart in each country will assist ADB in identifying the TA focal agency 
based on the scope of the government’s requests. The participating governments will mobilize 
key government staff and national organizations to participate in undertaking analytical work and 
receiving technical advice through on-the-job experience or appropriate training to help build 
country capacity for urban development. Close coordination will be maintained with resident 
missions, other development partners, and relevant regional organizations and bodies during TA 
implementation.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.10 The TA will 
finance national and international consulting services. It is expected that consulting firms will be 
recruited to deliver project feasibility and preparation assistance (output 1), while individual 
consultants will be recruited to deliver demand-driven technical advice and capacity development 
(outputs 2 and 3). Unless there is justification to use time-based contracts, output-based contracts

5 
will be preferred. The consultants will consist of urban development specialists and engineers as 
primary experts, including financial, business, legal, procurement, social, environmental, and 
gender  experts,  and  other  experts  as  required.  The  experts  will  have  experience  in  their 
respective fields and demonstrate sound technical knowledge of  urban development. Also, 
resource persons may be engaged with specialized expertise for very short-term work through 
resource person engagements. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
TA will be implemented over 60 months, commencing in May 2020. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
18.  Since ADB is the executing agency, the financial management, procurement, and integrity 
risks during TA implementation are assessed to be low. However, the TA will support thorough 
financial management, procurement, and integrity risk assessments for the ensuing investment 
projects in the target countries.11 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Pacific Urban Development Investment Project Enhancement and Capacity Development 
Facility, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
11 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
